story: Earliest known recording of rare British weather phenomenon discoveredA medieval text refers to what researchers believe is the first account in the UK of ball lightning which is still not explained today and is associated with thunderstormsLightning balls are associated with thunderstorms Image: Getty ImagesByTim HanlonNews Reporter:,  Jan | commentsResearchers have found what could be the earliest known account of unexplained balls of lightning in the th century that continue to puzzle scientists today.Ball lightning is usually reported during thunderstorms where large spherical objects of light, from a few centimetres to several metres wide, form and generally last for longer than normal lightning.There is scarce scientic details about their existence with some reports that they could form after lightning hits the ground and then ignites silicon oxide in dirt. Debate over what causes it has passed through the centuries and now physicist Emeritus Professor Brian Tanner and historian Professor Giles Gasper, of Durham University, have come across a reference to ball lightning while exploring a medieval text written more than  years ago. The account by the th century Benedictine monk Gervase, of Christ Church Cathedral Priory, Canterbury, pre-dates the previous earliest known description of ball lightning recorded in England by nearly  years, the researchers suggest.  Writing on June , , Gervase stated that a marvellous sign descended near London. He described a dense and dark cloud, emitting a white substance which grew into a spherical shape under the cloud, from which a fiery globe fell towards the river.Prof Tanner said: Ball lightning is a rare weather event that is still not understood today.Gervaseaposs description of a white substance coming out of the dark cloud, falling as a spinning fiery sphere and then having some horizontal motion is very similar to historic and contemporary descriptions of ball lightning.  If Gervase is describing ball lightning, as we believe, then this would be the earliest account of this happening in England that has so far been discovered. Before the text was revealed, the earliest report of ball lightning from England dates back to a great thunderstorm in Widecombe, Devon, on October  . Gervaseaposs Chronicle and other works now exist in only three manuscripts - one in the British Library, and two at the University of Cambridge. The Latin text was edited by Bishop William Stubbs in  and there is no translation into English. The researchers previously examined the monkaposs records of eclipses and a description of the splitting of the image of the crescent moon. Prof Gasper said: Given that Gervase appears to be a reliable reporter, we believe that his description of the fiery globe on the Thames on June   was the first fully convincing account of ball lightning anywhere. The findings are published in the Royal Meteorological Societyaposs journal, Weather. news uk-news every-covid-rule-being-lted-"UK records  new coronavirus daily deathsByMalvika PadinTrends Writer:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments Boris Johnson has confirmed that all Covid Plan B measures will come to an end in England today, on Thursday January . This means that mandatory mask-wearing on public transport and in shops, work-from-home guidance and the need for Covid passes will all be axed, despite rates of Omicron infection still surging across the country. UK will revert to Plan A with a focus on vaccine rollout, with Health Secretary Sajid Javid warning last Wednesday that itaposs not the end of the road eventhe number of cases are falling.This means that the end of Plan B does not mean the end of restrictions altogether. Here are the rules being removed today and what will remain. What restrictions will be removed when Plan B ends As of Today, Thursday, January , Covid passes for large venues will end. However, Boris Johnson said that venues would have the right to choose on whether or not they want to continue with the policy.Work-from-home guidance ended last week, with people ing to offices almost immediately after it was axed. Similarly, face coverings are no longer a legal requirement in public spaces including transport and shops. Face masks will also no longer be required in classrooms. Though the government no longer mandates wearing masks in any setting, Johnson added urged that people should still think about wearing a mask when in public environments, particularly in crowded or enclosed spaces. Restrictions on visiting care homes will also be eased. But Mr Javid warned that the end of Plan B shouldnapost be seen as the finish line. He urged people to continue taking protective measures including washing hands, ventilating rooms and self-isolatingpositive. Anyone who has yet to receive their Covid vaccines are also being urged to come forward. Which Covid rules will remain   Along with self-isolating for at least five full daysyou get a positive Covid test, the requirement to take lateral flow tests when travelling internationally will remain in place. While legal requirements stay in place for now, Johnson said he hoped to not have to renew self-isolation rules when they expire on March . He added that the aim is to remove the legal requirement for people to isolate after testing positive and replace it with advice and guidance as the virus becomes endemic.  For now, anyone planning to travel abroad need to book and pay for a Covid test before coming back to England - although this will change on February  from amyouaposre double-vaccinated. From now until then the test - either lateral flow or PCR - will have to be taken after you arrive back. If the test comes back positive, you need to self-isolate. Those who arenapost fully vaccinated need to book and pay for day two and day eight tests. You will also have to quarantine at home or the place youaposre staying for  full days. story: Everything we know so far about more contagious new ‘stealth Omicron’ Covid strainEarly data suggests the BA. iant could be . times more infectious than the original Omicron strain, but initial studies have not shown a dference in the risk of hospitalisationUK health officials are officially monitoring a new Covid- strain, nicknamed “stealth Omicron Image: Getty ImagesByLeonie Chao-Fong:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments UK health officials are officially monitoring a new Covid- strain, nicknamed “stealth Omicron ”, that appears to be more contagious than the original Omicron strain. Early data suggests that BA., a sub-iant believed to have emerged from a mutation of the Omicron coronavirus iant, may be both more transmissible and better able to evade vaccines than the more common BA. sub-lineage.Currently the BA. lineage accounts for % of all cases globally but in Denmark, the BA. has grown rapidly.In the last week of , it accounted for % of all Covid- cases. By the second week of , it accounted for % of cases. On Wednesday, it was reported that BA. had become the dominant strain in Denmark.In a national address on Wednesday, Danish Health Minister Magnus Heunicke said: “There is no evidence that the BA. iant causes more disease, but it must be more contagious.”  Initial calculations by Denmarkaposs top infectious disease authority, Statens Serum Institut, show BA. could be . times more infectious than BA.. So far, early data has not shown a dference in the risk of hospitalisation for BA. compared to BA.. There is some indication that it is more contagious, especially for the unvaccinated, but that it can also infect people who have been vaccinated to a greater extent, SSIaposs technical director Tyra Grove Krause said at the briefing on Wednesday. The BA. has been nicknamed “stealth Omicron” as it is poses a challenge for scientists to track, unlike the original Omicron that stood out on the widely-used PCR tests without the need for extra genome sequencing. The new strain shows up as being S-gene positive under PCR tests, whereas the BA. did not.  According to the World Health Organisation, BA. sequences have been reported in more than  countries, including the UK, Sweden, Norway, Singapore and India. On Friday, the UK Health Security Agency designated BA. a “iant under investigation” – one level below a “iant of concern” – saying it could have a growth advantage. It is the nature of viruses to evolve and mutate, so itaposs to be expected that we will continue to see new iants emerge, Dr Meera Chand, incident director at the UKHSA, said. Our continued genomic surveillance allows us to detect them and assess whether they are signicant.  So far, there is insufficient evidence to determine whether BA. causes more severe illness than omicron BA., but data is limited and UKHSA continues to investigate.” In the UK, some  cases of the BA. sub-lineage have been sequenced, according to Reuters, and the UKHSA said early analysis suggested an increased growth rate compared to BA.. Imperial College London’s Tom Peacock, one of the first virologists to raise the alarm over Omicron, tweeted that very early observations from India and Denmark suggest there is no dramatic dference in severity compared to BA.. This data should become more solidin the coming weeks.” He added that there is likely to be minimal dferences in vaccine effectiveness against BA. and BA.. Personally, Iaposm not sure BA. is going to have a substantial impact on the current Omicron wave of the pandemic. Several countries are near, or even past the peak of BA. waves. I would be very surprisedBA. caused a second wave at this point. Even with slightly higher transmissibility this absolutely is not a Delta-Omicron change and instead is likely to be slower and more subtle, he continued. title: family told pay over 1600
story: Family told to pay over £, after sons move out in bedroom tax ordealParents Philip Elliot, , and Elizabeth Aslett, , said they feel they are being punished for pushing their sons to do better with their lives by moving out of their three-bed council home to go to uni and collegeParents Philip Elliot, , and Elizabeth Aslett, , were in shock when they received a message saying they owed £,. as their bedroom tax had changed Image: Nottingham Post   BPM MediaByEllie DanemannAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Jan | comments A mum was left in tears as her family is embroiled in a bedroom tax nightmare after they were told to pay more than £, after their two sons moved away.Parents Philip Elliot, , and Elizabeth Aslett, , have been left frustrated at the tax payment and say they will struggle to pay the money.The family have lived in a three-bedroom council house in Bilborough, Nottingham for nearly  years. Their two sons - Ryan Aslett, , and Lewis Aslett,  - left the family home in September of last year to go to university and college, NottinghamshireLive reports. Before they moved out, the parents say they spoke to officials explaining the situation and said their sons would still need their bedrooms for when they come back for the holidays. The couple claim they were initially told this was fine, but then earlier this month they received a message saying they owed £,. as their bedroom tax had changed. Are you enduring a bedroom tax hell  Email webnews@mirror to tell your story They received £, each month from Universal Credit as well as £ from Employment and Support Allowance and Personal Independence Payment [PIP] support.The amount recipients receive towards housing costs may be reduced when a home has spare bedrooms. Bedroom tax means a claimant will receive less in housing benefit or housing cost element in a Universal Credit claim when living in a housing association or council house and deemed to have one or more spare bedrooms. The family were left in utter shock when they were told they needed to pay £,. in the dispute over bedroom tax. Philip said: We told them in August this was going to happen in September, the lady said everything was fine. The money was looking a bit dferent in November so I was a little worried. When I found out it was a shock, nobody had said we owed them money. Weaposve got welfare rights involved and itaposs been sent to the appeal stage. The couple explained they were unable to work due to their disabilities, which means they will struggle to pay the money or be able to survive off the smaller payments. Elizabeth added: I burst into tears and cried, it was so annoying. We donapost know what is round the corner, we had both the boys home for six weeks over Christmas, theyaposre coming back in the next week or so.for our daily newsletter to keep up to date with all the essential information atwww.mirror emailThe DWP apologised for how the familyaposs case had been handled and added that staff were in touch to help them with the appeals process. The family now fear for their future remaining in the house. Philip added: Weaposve got two boys trying to better themselves in le, weaposve put them in the right direction and now we are getting penalised for it. We canapost afford to keep it anymore, we donapost want to move, we donapost have the money to move. We are stuck. A DWP spokesman said: We are very sorry for how Mr Elliott and Ms Assett’s claim has been handled and have been in touch to apologise and to help them with the appeals process. “We have also reviewed their benefits to ensure they are receiving their correct entitlement. The Mirror contacted the DWP for comment. Andrew vehemently denies the allegations. In the interview, where Andrew was quizzed over his association with his billionaire paedophile Jeffrey Epstein, the Duke of York said he didnapost remember meeting Giuffre. However, she claims that on the night of one of their alleged encounters, Andrew sweated heavily as they danced at Tramp nightclub in London.  The Prince told Newsnight: There’s a slight problem with the sweating because I have a peculiar medical condition which is that I don’t sweat or I didn’t sweat at the time and that was…was it…yes, I didn’t sweat at the time because I had suffered what I would describe as an overdose of adrenalin in the Falkland’s War when I was shot at and I simply…it was almost impossible for me to sweat. title: healthy fit british dad 68
story: Healthy and fit British dad, , drowns in hotel yoga tragedy after moving to IndiaIain Francis, , had recently retired to India and was enjoying his daily ritual of yoga practice at the riverside by his hotel when he accidentally fell into the water and drownedIain Francis had recently retired to IndiaByAnita Merritt:,  Jan | commentsA aposhealthy and fitapos father died in a yoga tragedy at a hotel after moving to India. Iain Francis, , had recently retired to India and was enjoying his daily ritual of yoga practice at the riverside by his hotel when he accidentally fell into the water and drowned. The dad-of-three, from Moretonhampstead, is believed to have hit his head during the fall on March , , and is likely to have been unconscious by the time he went into the water.An inquest at Exeter’s County Hall on January , heard the family had endured a long wait for more information surrounding his death from the Foreign Commonwealth Office and Indian police authorities due to the coronavirus pandemic, reports Devon Live. The -year-old, who had no known medical conditions, was described by his daughter Angela as having been aposextremelyapos healthy and fit for his age and did yoga every day to help ease pain in his hips, knees and sometimes also his feet.  In a statement, she recalled: He went to India in October  to enjoy this retirement warmer climate where he could stretch and climatise. He intended indeed to come back in the spring. Mr Francis had previously been a plumber for many years but also had an extensive career working in microfinance as a financial consultant in foreign agricultural programmes. He worked in  countries including Nigeria, Vietnam and Bangladesh. After retiring he travelled to India on his own and had been staying in the district of Koppal in Karnataka. The location of his death was Hanumanahalli Thungabhandra River Gangavathi. His daughter recalled the majority of his trip had been spent near the sea in Goa. Angela said: He was a strong swimmer, although he did not attempt to go in the water much or for long periods in later years.  The manager of the hotel where Mr Francis was staying told police in India that every day he would do yoga and body exercises at a riverbank near the hotel. On the day of his death he left the hotel at .pm and at pm the hotel manager was informed he had fallen in the river. He recalled he had gone to the river and saw Mr Francis floating in the water wearing shorts, and his belongings were on the bank of the river. The police investigation confirmed Mr Francis had accidentally fallen down into the river and had hit his head on a rock on his way into the water. The conclusion was he had died by accidental drowning and there was no third party involvement. A post mortem examination conducted in India confirmed the cause of Mr Francisaposs death was drowning. It was noted that there were lacerations to his scalp and a deep injury on the left side of the top of his head. Recording a narrative conclusion, coroner Philip Spinney said: “The deceased died from the effects of drowning.” Following the inquest, his daughters paid tribute to Mr Francis and said: Our dad was wonderfully caring, funny, sensitive and generous. He had a spirit, heart and presence like no one  and he will always be dearly missed. title: highway code changes cyclists important
story: Highway Code changes for cyclists - important new rules for those on bikesCycling on the roads can dangerous. We take a look at the latest new changes to the Highway Code being brought in for Rush hour can be a hectic time for people on two wheelsByHarry ThompsonTrends Writer:,  Jan | comments The Highway Code is set to have some crucial updates made to it this week. The changes are set to impact all kinds of road users but will have the overall goal of making roads safer for people on foot, bikes and horses.The changes are coming into play after a huge consultation with the public was conducted to find out what people wanted and how they used the roads. , people took part in the consultation, with the government saying that most people who responded were in favour of the proposed changes.The new rules will work to make motorists more aware of cyclists and pedestrians, ensuring a safer experience for all road users.When are the Highway Code changes coming in January   The changes will be made from Saturday, January , with eight changes in total set to come into force. We take a look at all the ones likely to affect cyclists Road user hierarchy Three new changes are coming in that will impact road use hierarchy. This rule enforces the idea that motorists need to be more aware of cyclists, and cyclists need to be more aware of pedestrians.The change in rules will see users who are most at risk moved to the top of the hierarchy.The government website says: The hierarchy places those road users most at risk in the event of a collision at the top of the hierarchy. It does not remove the need for everyone to behave responsibly. People crossing at junctions  According to the government, the new update will mean that:When people are crossing or waiting to cross at a junction, other traffic should give waypeople have started crossing and traffic wants to turn into the road, the people crossing have priority and the traffic should give way people driving, riding a motorcycle or cycling must give way to people on a zebra crossing and people walking and cycling on a parallel crossingA parallel crossing is similar to a zebra crossing, but includes a cycle route alongside the black and white stripes. Walking cycling and riding in shared spaces  Shared areas will ask that people on pushbikes respect the safety of people walking, although pedestrians too must take care not to endanger anyone. The government says: People cycling are asked to:not pass people walking, riding a horse or driving a horse-drawn vehicle closely or at high speed, particularly from behind slow down when necessary and let people walking know they are thereremember that people walking may be deaf, blind or partially sighted avoid passing a horse on the horse’s leftPositioning in the road when cycling  The road position that cyclists take up when using highways is due to have updated guidance. The government will now ask cyclists to begin:riding in the centre of their lane on quiet roads, in slower-moving traffic and at the approach to junctions or road narrowings keeping at least . metresaway from the kerb edgewhen riding on busy roads with vehicles moving faster than themThis section of the code will also impact people riding in groups, saying they:should be considerate of the needs of other road users when riding in groups can ride  abreast - and it can be safer to do so, particularly in larger groups or when accompanying children or less experienced riders Cyclists are also asked to be aware of people driving behind them and let them overtakethey wish to. This might include moving into a single file or even stoppingnecessary.It also discusses that people riding bikes need to:take care when passing parked vehicles, leaving enough roomto avoid being hita car door is opened watch out for people walking into their pathOvertaking when cycling  Updates are expected about safe passing distances, as well as speeds. The government say this will include:leaving at least . metreswhen overtaking people cycling at speeds of up to mph, and giving them more space when overtaking at higher speeds passing people riding horses or driving horse-drawn vehicles at speeds under  mph and allowing at least  metresof space allowing at least  metresof space and keeping to a low speed when passing people walking in the road This also means waiting behind someone and not overtaking until it is safe to do so by meeting these spaces. The update will also confirm that people cycling may pass slower-moving or stationary traffic on their right or left, although they are advised to be careful as people they pass might not be able to see them. People cycling at junctions  When turning in or out of a side road you need to give way to people waiting to cross or who are already walking across. The government also say: Some junctions now include small cycle traffic lights at eye-level height, which may allow cyclists to move separately from or before other traffic. People cycling are encouraged to use these facilities where they make their journey safer and easier. If there are no separate cycling facilities on a junction, then people on bikes should behave in the same way as car drivers. This will mean, where safe, positioning yourself in the middle of your correct lane at junctions. When it comes to turning right, advice is be handed down for cyclists using junctions that involve making the turn in two stages:stage  - when the traffic lights turn green, go straight ahead to the location marked by a cycle symbol and turn arrow on the road, and then stop and wait stage  - when the traffic lights on the far side of the junctionturn green, complete the manoeuvre The new advice also adds that people on bikes have priority when going straight ahead on junctions.They have priority over traffic waiting to turn into or out of a side road, unless road signs or markings indicate otherwise, the government says. People cycling are asked to watch out for people driving intending to turn across their path, as people driving ahead may not be able to see them. Cycling on a roundabout  Drivers and motorcyclists should now give priority to cyclists on roundabouts. The guidance will say they should:not attempt to overtake people cycling within that person’s lane allow people cycling to move across their path as they travel around the roundaboutCyclists will still be able to remain in the left-hand lane when going across or around a roundabout. The new guidance is due that will tell motorists to pay extra attention to this, taking care not to cut off cyclists doing this. title: huge drive thru kebab shop
story: Huge drive-thru kebab shop seeks to open in UK first which will rival likes of KFCThe new fast food joint would serve hungry drivers and diners at its two-storey restaurant which is planned to take prime position in Bolton, Greater ManchesterA recently submitted plan seeks to convert an empty building into a two-storey kebab restaurantByChris GeeLaura SharmanNews Reporter:,  Jan | commentsA huge drive-thru kebab restaurant is on the cards for Greater Manchester which could rival the likes of McDonaldaposs and KFC. Plans have been submitted for a two-storey restaurant in Bolton town centre to serve the classic late night feast to both indoor diners and passing drivers. Documents suggest converting an empty premises into the drive-thru restaurant under the German Doner Kebab name. It would transform the currently shabby and deserted building into an urban chic kebab joint equipped for all.Glossy CGI images published by Bolton Council in support of the application show its intended transformation, reports Manchester Evening News.The site was previously used by charities including the Mental Health Independent Support Team and Bolton NICE, which develops community and business enterprises and job opportunities.  Synergie Holdings submitted the proposal and opening hours for the venture are unknown at this stage. Five on-site parking spots would be created at the site, according to the application. Responding to the form, Boltonaposs highways department said it will need more information before giving an opinion. title: im worlds most prolific sperm
story: Im worlds most prolic sperm donor with  kids - I give it away free on FacebookRetired teacher -year-old Clive Jones was unable to become an official sperm donor but now gives it away for free to people on Facebook and wants to get to  babies before giving upClive Jones offers his sperm to people for free Image: Clive JonesByKelly-Ann MillsNews ReporterBen Lyons:,  Jan | commentsA man who has been donating his sperm for the last nine years claims to be the worldaposs most prolic donor and says he has fathered  children and has nine more on the way.Retired teacher Clive Jones donates his sperm using the unregulated world of Facebook, where he claims he found an overwhelming demand.Having only started donating his sperm aged , but was unable to become an official sperm donor because banks have an upper donor age limit of . Health experts have issued a medical warning regarding his activities, saying that all donors and patients should be treated at a licensed UK clinic.Mr Jones, , himself told Derbyshire Live heaposs had a lot of people question him over why he does it, but believes they would understandthey saw the happiness it brings to the families he provides his free donations to. He said: Iaposm probably the worldaposs most prolic sperm donor with now being at  aposbabiesapos, well,  babies born, nine ongoing pregnancies. I might continue for another few years. Get to  anyway. I know of clinics and sperm merchants with greater numbers but they donapost donate, but rather sell semen. I think people would understand morethey saw the messages I get and the photos of the babies with very happy mothers. I feel the happiness it brings. I once had a grandmother message me thanking me for her granddaughter. I do it for free, though sometimes ask a bit for petrol. Itaposs illegal to charge and doesnapost seem right to take money when I have more than them. Mr Jones, who has three grown-up children of his own, said: It all started in May, over nine years ago. For some people, having children is very important as it was for me. I read in some newspapers the plight of some people that canapost have children. Reading the newspaper, it explained how people were using Facebook to make arrangements. I thought I could help so I put a post on one of the sites. I wasnapost expecting any response with me saying how old I was, but I had a lady in Derby contacting me within an hour asking me to help that evening.  Iaposve not advertised Iaposm a donor in years. It has not quite worked out as I had guessed, Iaposm just as busy now and have so many people contact me through people just talking, referring. The Human Fertilisation and Embryology Authority has issued a medical warning regarding Mr Jonesapos activities, saying that all donors and patients should be treated at a licensed UK clinic. A spokeswoman for the authority said: As the regulator of UK fertility treatment and research we donapost have the powers to stop people from making their own arrangements for sperm donation but we do want to help them get the information and advice they need to make the best informed choices, which is why we always encourage both donors and patients to be treated at a licensed UK clinic. If arrangements are made outside of the clinic environment there can be medical and legal risks, for example, without the proper consents in place the donor is likely to be seen as the legal parent, with all the rights and responsibilities that involves. Clinics will also rigorously test all donors for medical and hereditary illnesses. That’s why we always encourage sperm donors and patients to go to a licensed clinic, where these medical and legal issues are taken care of for them, and where the welfare of the child is always of primary concern.  Mr Jones says heaposs been married since , but now lives apart from his we who he says is not at all happy about what he does.Back in , Mr Jones appeared in  Men  Babies, a Channel  documentary which follows the lives of four men who donate their sperm for free to women who contacted them online. A clip from the show was featured on Gogglebox, which has received more than four million views on Facebook. Of the  children he claims to have fathered, Mr Jones says heaposs met around  of the babies which are located within around a -mile radius of Derby, including in Birmingham, Stoke and Nottingham. After first making contact, Mr Jones says he then gets to know the couple, who are often same-sex or cannot have children of their own, and discuss when their ovulation cycle is. He said he then places the date on his planner, and when he gets the call saying ovulation is only hours away, he jumps into his van and drives close to where they live. Describing how he does it, Mr Jones previously told Derbyshire Live : I drive somewhere where Iaposm not likely to be disturbed and go into the back of the van and pull the curtains down. Then I take the cup and a syringe so the stuff canapost come out, put a bag under my arm and text them to say Iaposm outside and Iaposll be round in three minutes. If that doesnapost work sometimes they suggest I meet them in a car park. I can tell how nervous they are. No other donor does it from their van normally, they go to the front door and ask to use the toilet. today paid a solo visit to a mental health service she set up with Meghan Markle almost three years ago. Shout - a text service for people struggling with their mental health - was Kate and Prince William’s first major project with Meghan and Prince Harry.It launched in May  following a £million investment from the Royal Foundation, when the royals were dubbed the Fab Four. However, today when visiting the service in Londonaposs Notting Hill, Kate was flying solo as she met volunteers and those who have raised funds for the organisation. Among them was a teenage Scout who raised £, for the service by sleeping outside in a hammock for a year. Kate met Leo Street, , and called him ‘an inspiration’ after he braved temperatures as low as minus five to raise money for the charity.The duchess, who wore a £ olive green Derek Lam dress and £ ASOS earrings, joked: “There really isn’t a big enough Scout badge for that. During her visit, Kate also met clinical supervisors, volunteers, and fundraisers to thank them for their invaluable efforts to ensure that vital mental health support is available across the UK at any time of day or night. story: Maida Vale: Mum had texted friend saying psychotic ex would kill her before her deathThe politan Police issued an arrest warrant for Leon McCaskre three weeks before he brutally killed Yasmin Chkai on the streets of Maida ValeYasmin Chkai , a mum-of-two, was stabbed on the streets of Maida Vale, west London on Monday morning Image: Yasmin Chkai TwitterByMilo BoydNews Reporter:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan A woman told a friend that her apospsychoticapos ex-husband would kill her before he stabbed her to death in the street. The politan Police had issued an arrest warrant for Leon McCaskre three weeks before he brutally killed Yasmin Chkai on the streets of Maida Vale, west London on Monday morning. As the -year-old repeatedly stabbed the mum-of-two with a kitchen kne, a -year-old motorist allegedly ploughed his car into the killer. Paramedics were unable to save either Yasmin, a qualied childminder and masters student, or McCaskre. Before her death, the mum-of-two had told friend Adele-Sara Richards that he had put cameras in her flat and had stolen her mail and phone in order to get her personal information. Ms Richard said that in April  she messaged her to say: Heaposs had cameras in my house recording me for months. She went on: Heaposs stolen my mail, my phone, has access to all my personal data. I think he will kill me. Iaposve tried everything. Family members, including two young men thought to be her  and -year-old sons, said that the -year-old had a panic alarm installed in her flat. They also accused Scotland Yard of doing nothing to help the mum, who they said took a restraining order out against McCaskre and orced him three years ago. Records show that McCaskre was wanted for failing to appear in court on January  after breaching stalking orders banning him from contacting Yasmin, The Times reports.  Deon Nelson-Wright, a close friend and former flatmate of the mum, said she knew the psychotic man spelt bad news for her pal from the moment they met. She told The Mirror: I knew this was going to happen. I just knew it. He was psychotic. A petition has been launched dubbing the unnamed driver a hero and calling for him not to face criminal charges. On Tuesday he was released on bail after being arrested on suspicion of murder. A friend told The Mirror that the driver, thought to be a dad-of-three, was in shock and living in a nightmare. title: mum eleven month old baby
story: Mum and eleven-month-old baby in pram hit by car mounting pavementA woman and her -month-old baby in a pram were taken to hospital after they were hit by a car that went up onto the pavement in Sutton Coldfield after crashing with another vehicleA mum and her baby were both hit by a car in Sutton Coldfield Image: BPM MEDIAByTim HanlonNews Reporter:,  Jan | comments A mum and her -month-old baby have been taken to hospital after they were hit by a car that mounted a pavement in Sutton Coldfield. The woman was walking with a push chair when two cars crashed and one went onto the pathway and struck them, reported BirminghamLive.Police and ambulance crews were called to the incident on Hollyfield Road South, in Reddicap, at around .am on Wednesday. It was a section of road close to a parade of shops and it led to the street being closed off to through traffic and pedestrians. The ambulance service sent two ambulances, two paramedic officers and the West Midlands Central Accident, Resuscitation  Emergencyteam. The woman was said to have suffered serious injuries and was taken to the area’s major trauma centre, Queen Elizabeth Hospital in Birmingham. While the baby was initially said to have potentially serious injuries and was taken to Birmingham Children’s Hospital in the city centre police later said that their condition was not serious. A spokesman for West Midlands Ambulance Service said: “We were called to reports of a collision between a car and pedestrians on Hollyfield Road South at .am on Wednesday . “Two ambulances, two paramedic officers and the West Midlands Care Team were sent to the scene. “On arrival we discovered two pedestrians, a woman and a baby, who had been injured in the incident. “The woman was treated for serious injuries, not believed to be le-threatening, before being taken to Queen Elizabeth Hospital, Birmingham. title: sainsburys john lewis ask shoppers
story: Sainsburys and John Lewis ask shoppers to keep wearing face masks despite rule changeSainsburys, John Lewis and Waitrose will ask customers in England to keep wearing face masks despite the Government scrapping plan B measures and their mask mandate from tomorrowJohn Lewis is among the group of leading stores that will continue asking staff and shoppers to wear face masks Image: Getty ImagesByRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Jan | comments Leading supermarkets will ask staff and customers to continue wearing face masks after plan B measures end tomorrow.Sainsburyaposs, John Lewis and Waitrose will remind shoppers to wear a covering in store despite the Government scrapping the rule as a legal requirement from Thursday. However, Morrisons has confirmed they will welcome maskless shoppers, BBC reports.The retailers said visitors wonapost be forced to wear masks, but they will be encouraged in order to keep staff and other people safe. Downing Street rolled out Plan B at the start of December to battle the surge of Omicron cases. The measures are being lted from tomorrow because the mutation has already peaked, the government has said. Though no longer a legal issue, the Government is still advising Brits to wear a mask in enclosed or crowded spaces, and when meeting strangers.  Retail worker trade union USDAW is also urging shoppers to observe Covid safety measures. Speaking to the broadcaster, Sainsburyaposs said safety was its highest priority. The supermarket plans to put up posters and remind customers over the tannoy about their guidance. In a statement, they said: In Scotland and Wales face coverings remain mandatory for those who can wear them in our stores, in line with the latest government restrictions.  We continue to have a range of safety measures in all of our stores, including screens and sanitising stations. Department store John Lewis, which owns Waitrose, will be suggesting people wear masks but say it will be down to iniduals to make a personal choice. Meanwhile, electronics store Currys will ask staff to wear masks in-store and while delivering products. But customers will not be expected to do so.  We will continue to assess our approach based on infection rates and colleague feedback, the company said. Usdaw, which represents , retail workers, said the Governmentaposs move to end the measure was deeply disappointing while infections rates remain high. General secretary Paddy Lillis said: We hope all retailers will continue to put staff and customer safety first. Wearing a face covering is an important measure to help protect workers who have no option but to interact with the public. Rail operators also plan to ask travellers to adhere to mask-wearing rules on their services.  Boris Johnson confirmed all Plan B measures will end tomorrow. This means that mandatory mask-wearing on public transport and in shops, work-from-home guidance and the need for Covid passes will all be axed, despite rates of Omicron infection still surging across the country. UK will revert to Plan A with a focus on vaccine rollout, with Health Secretary Sajid Javid warning last Wednesday that itaposs not the end of the road eventhe number of cases are falling.This means that the end of Plan B does not mean the end of restrictions altogether. title: school should scrap hair rules
story: School should scrap hair rules and let kids embrace their heritageAfter a ticking off at her sons school, Eva Simpson knows only too well how out-of-touch guidelines can be. And she applauds the St Albans headteacher who is ripping up the rulebookEva Simpson says schools should scrap their hair rulesImage: Getty ImagesopinionByEva Simpson:,  Jan | comments Like most parents on their child’s first day of ­ secondary school, I was filled with immense pride.My son looked so smart in his new unorm – blazer, tie, shirt, gleaming shoes. I took loads of pictures to show family and friends.When we arrived at the school, a teacher pointed to my son and called out “can this boy’s parent come and see me I stepped forward proudly. I didn’t expect to be singled out for how well turned out and smart my son looked on his first day of big school. “Good morning,” said the teacher. “I’m just wonderingyou read the school’s policy on hair  Your son’s haircut is in contravention of that.” I was stunned. Contravention. What was he on about My son had a perfectly normal hair cut, one that he’d had all through primary school. A short crop, similar to one sported by US President Barack Obama. But as far as the school was concerned it was an “extreme” haircut because it wasn’t a number four or above. In other words it was too short. I won’t lie, I was so upset I was on the verge of tears. Of course in typical British fashion I apologised profusely and assured him it wouldn’t happen again. But I was fuming. It immediately created a ­ision when there didn’t need to be one and left a very bad taste. There have been too many incidents of black children being penalised for hair ­“transgressions”. So I was heartened to read about St Albans headteacher Julie Richardson who has ripped up the school’s rule book on hair and thrown it out of the window.Now kids can come in with cornrows, Afros, short hair, whatever, without being put into isolation and missing valuable teaching time.Too many unorm policies around hair are ridiculous. They ignore children’s cultural heritage. Black schoolgirls for instance have sometimes been banned from having braids as they’re classed as hair extensions, even though they’re neat and mean the child can get ready for school much quicker. This fosters resentment, all to the detriment of the child. Part of the problem is the lack of ­ersity among school governors. It’s a closed shop. Many schools, especially those with a large black student body, have practically no black representation among the governing body and that needs to change. So I applaud Ms Richardson. I hope more schools take a leaf out of her book. title: socialite who became known lion
story: Socialite who became known as the Lion Man of Cha dies aged John Rendall and Anthony ‘Ace’ Bourke were flatmates who ran a furniture store. They came across a lion cub called Christian in the pet department of Harrods department store and bought the animalJohn Rendall and Anthony Bourke with Christian the lion in their London home Image: SHARED CONTENT UNITByDeborah Collcutt:,  Jan | commentsThe trio were as common a sight in seventies Cha as mini-skirts and Mary Quant eyeliner, driving around in a convertible Mercedes, dining in the finest restaurants and partying with glamorous women. And one of them was a lion. Christian the lion cub was famous among the bohemian and glamorous social world which congregated in that trendy part of south west London and included The Beatles, Mick Jagger, Jimi Hendrix and Vivienne Westwood, as well as his owners Anthony ‘Ace’ Bourke and John Rendall, whose death at the age of  was announced today. The Lion Man of Cha, as Rendall came to be known, and Bourke were flatmates who ran a furniture store, coincidentally called Sophistocat. They came across Christian in the pet department of Harrods department store, where back in the day you could buy tapirs, snakes, monkeys, pumas and even lions as well. This was before the Endangered Species Act of , which made it illegal for exotic creatures to be sold to the public. For the princely sum of  guineas – about £, in today’s money – Christian was theirs.  The men set about feeding Christian from a detailed diet sheet supplied by Harrods: raw egg and vitamins for breakfast, raw meat — usually chopped beef or rabbit — for lunch and supper, and, as a special treat, a delicious marrow-filled bone at night. Local restaurants and butchers offered steaks that were past their sell-by date, and cut-price meat. But exercise soon became a concern as Rendall and Bourke didn’t know where to walk him in this densely populated and traffic-choked corner of London. The local vicar came to their rescue when he offered Christian the use of a churchyard, near the shop. When he was nearly a year old, Christian had grown rapidly and his owners heartbreakingly decided they had to set him free. Lion expert George Adamson agreed to rehome him at Kora reserve in Kenya, so two weeks after Christian’s first and last birthday in England in August, , they headed for Africa. When they took Christian for his first walk in the bush, they witnessed the animal instincts that would ensure his survival. Spotting a lost cow in the bush, Christian instantly froze and began stalking his prey, stealthily creeping forwards. George was worried about the cow’s horns and told the men to grab Christian.  For the first time ever, the lion turned and snarled at them, leaving the pair profoundly shaken by the transformation in Christian from a biddable pet to a deadly hunter. Although sad that it was time to say goodbye, the pair were relieved to see he possessed the instincts he needed to stay alive. “Once we’d got him to Africa, I think Ace particularly had a real sense of, ‘my God, we’ve done it. Phew’.” said John years later. “But it was also sad: this wonderful presence had gone.” A year later, in the summer of , the men ed to Kora to see George and, they hoped, Christian. George warned them not to get their hopes up as Christian, now the head of a small pride, hadn’t been seen for weeks. But when they landed in Nairobi, George was beaming. “The lions turned up this morning,” he said. “Christian must have known you were coming.” The moment he heard his former owners’ voices, Christian ran towards them, grunting with excitement. Watching the lb lion bounding towards them at about  miles an hour was a breathtaking moment – would he greet or attack them  Bracing themselves, suddenly Christian was jumping up, rubbing their heads, and running backwards and forwards between them as he tried to embrace both men at the same time. He knew exactly who they were. The wonderful moment of reunion was captured on film and has since been watched more than  million views on YouTube. “I look at the photos of that meeting and realise how overwhelmed I was by the powerful emotion,” Rendall said in an interview. “At that moment, the gulf between humans and lions had been blurred by sheer euphoria.” Rendall, who was found dead in his study on Sunday by his magician son, Max, said in an interview once: “Christian changed my le forever and I will never forget him.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Daily MirrorLions,callToAction:ltpgtGet weekly highlights from Mirror editor Alison Phillips direct to your emaillt pgt,buttonText:,contentId:,newsletterImage:https:i-prod.mirror article.ece ALTERNATES sd _AlisonHeaderFinal.png,endpointUrl:https:response.pure interface list.php,profile:Reach_Mirror,isPureNewsLetter:true,pureMailingListId:Mirror - Alisons Newsletter,isDoubleOptIn:,newsletterSiteName:Mirror" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get weekly highlights from Mirror editor Alison Phillips direct to your emailInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: teen who faces internal decapitation
story: Exclusive: Teen who faces internal decapitation from rare condition cries as strangers gt £,Allesha Barnfield could become internally decapitated at any time due to a rare condition but after the Mirror helped her tell her story she is crying tears of joy and can fly to Spain for le saving surgeryAllesha is eagerly awaiting surgery in February to save her from this awful condition Image: The MirrorByHollie BoneNews Reporter:,  Jan | comments A teenager has thanked strangers whose incredible generosity has funded brain surgery to stop a rare condition from internally decapitating her.Allesha Barnfield, , from Highfield, South Yorkshire was diagnosed with Chiari Malformation in September  but is not eligible for surgery on the NHS. The condition means that the ligaments in Allesha’s spine are tense and tighter than usual, subsequently pulling her brain into her spinal canal which causes crippling headaches making sound and light unbearable for the teen.The potentially fatal condition can also lead to ‘internal decapitation’ or paralysis when the tension builds so much that these ligaments become severed. The former law student, whose dreams of becoming a lawyer were initially dashed by the devastating diagnosis, needed £, to fly to Spain and have an innovative new operation which will stop the malformation in her spine. Have you got an incredible story to tell  Email webnews@mirror But following an exclusive Mirror appeal to help her raise the funds she has received an incredible £, from people around the world. Allesha said: “The surgery is booked, all I need to book now is my flights and work out who is going to come with me. “I’m literally so happy it’s unreal, I can’t believe it. “The Mirror is the reason this has all happened, I donapost know where I would be without all these amazing people who have donated and the help I have had to raise awareness.  “Thousands of people have donated, some of them I’ve never met. “I rang my sister crying when we hit £,. I’ve had to take the last few days just to process it. “I never thought I would even manage to raise the money I needed, never mind do it in a few days.” Allesha had started looking for answers three years ago when she was struck down with daily headaches so severe that she can’t bear to look at light or hear anything louder than a whisper. The teenager was forced to give up her placement with a law firm and quit college just as she was about to go to university, instead spending her le confined in a dark quiet room.  Now her surgery at the Filum System clinic in Barcelona is booked for February  and Allesha will be supported by her boyfriend, Kieran, . Although the recovery period ies between patients, Allesha hopes to be home and healthy in time for her th birthday in April, when her le can finally begin again. She said: “Hopefully I will be back up and better in time for my th birthday. “It’s the best birthday present I could ever ask for. “I want to go back and get ready for university and start studying law. “The next step is having the surgery and then taking the time to recover but I want to raise as much awareness as I can about Chiari Malformation. “Even though I’m terried I’m also so excited and feel like I have a new lease of le back. “Before this I just wanted to give up because I thought my le was over. “But now I have a chance to start again.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON NHSTeenagers" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. story: Vegan vows to boycott Subway for mocking Veganuary with Steakuary flyersVegan activist Jamie Carter has vowed to botcott Subway, after the chain sent out flyers encouraging people to follow Steakuary and Turkeyuary as well as VeganuaryJamie has been vegan for two years and vegetarian for  before that Image: Kennedy News and MediaByEmma RosemurgeyAudience Writer:,  Jan | comments A vegan has vowed never to step foot in a Subway ever again, after the sandwich chain sent degrading flyers allegedly mocking Venganuary, by suggesting customers enjoy alternatives such as Steakuary and Turkeyuary.Livid Jamie Carter received the leaflet through his door at the beginning of the month, advertising a range of sub options suited to Veganuary, Tunauary, ChickenTeriyakiuary and B.M.T.uary, and other meaty month names. Iaposm not happy, I felt disappointed. I thought I might fancy a Subway so went to seethey had any offers in the leaflet. I turned it over and to my dismay I felt they were making a mockery of Veganuary, Jamie, from Norwich, said. Iaposve never seen any company, let alone such a big one, make a mockery of Veganuary. They include so many meats like aposSteakuaryapos or aposTurkeybreastuary, it was just a marketing opportunity for them  Iaposd rather they just promoted Veganuary, it was unnecessary to add all the other terms. This should be a time of promoting a more ethical option. I was just pretty dumbfounded. Iaposve never seen any other wording like that. Iaposll happily boycott them now.The -year-old, who has been a vegan for two years and was previously vegetarian for  years, took to Facebook to vent about the absolute p***take pamphlet to his followers, who branded it pathetic and f***ing vile.Subway UK  Ireland very disappointed with you making a mockery of Veganuary, he wrote. Posting a leaflet promoting people to eat whoever they want instead of promoting a cruelty-free compassionate option. SHAME ON YOU. Now the animal rights activist has vowed to boycott Subway despite having at least  within walking distance of his home as he feels the chain have undone their efforts to support plant-based eating. Jamie said: This is a month where it should really be hitting home that thereaposs other tasty options. I posted it online to seeanyone  had the same feelings as me, and an awful lot of people do. That was the first time Iaposve ever addressed a big company directly and Iaposve still not had a response from them. Itaposs a leaflet with six vouchers inside - only one of which is for their plant-based section. The rest apply to any of their meat or dairy products. Other than the post, people have been contacting me [privately]. The general consensus is that people arenapost happy. I do generally speak to like-minded people and they think itaposs degrading to the cause. I thought [Subway] had made a step in the right direction by bringing out plant-based options and theyaposve done a  now. Itaposs like theyaposve undone their efforts so far. After posting online, Jamie received a number of responses from unamused followers who agreed it wasnapost the best move for the sandwich chain. Pathetic. Wouldnapost go there anyway, one wrote, while another added: F***ing vile to use the Veganuary word and [to] add flesh aposfleshanuaryapos it is literally taking the p***. I’m pleased I’m no regular at this place. This poster is not funny, a third wrote, while a fourth commented: They can stuff it! Iaposll make my own rolls and a lot cheaper too. story: Where youre most likely to catch Covid from gym to cinema, new study showsA new study has highlighted the exact risk you have of catching Covid- in ious locations – including where youre most likely to catch itHeavy exercise indoors can increase your risk of catching Covid Image: Getty ImagesByAriane Sohrabi-ShirazSEO Editor:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments There are certain things we do in our daily lives that increase the risk of catching Covid-. Two years into the coronavirus pandemic, normal le is slowly ing in England, with the easing of restrictions and rules. Despite Covid rates increasing thanks to the Omicron iant, the hospital admission rate has decreased. Even so, itaposs important to do all we can to avoid spreading Covid. Itaposs well known that certain places and activities can increase our risk, but a new study has offered clear estimates about the risk of Covid infection.So which activities are safe, and how safe exactly are they  Researchers have published a study in the peer-reviewed Environmental Science  Technology journal calculated the exact risk of catching Covid in ious environments. Where youaposre most likely to catch Covid  Displayed in a handy chart, the study has lists the percentage likelihood of becoming infected in dferent situations. For example,youaposre sitting in a crowded cinema with a mostly unmasked audience, thereaposs a % chance of being infected, assuming everyone in the room is silent. However,there are some people talking, the odds of infection jump to %. If the audience is masked, the risk of infection drops to a mere .%they stay silent, or %there is talking. Unsurprisingly, the risk of catching Covid is lowest in outdoor areas, and the risk is loweredpeople stay silent and wear a mask.  For example,youaposre standing with someone outside for a short period of time, and neither of you are talking, there is less than .% likelihood of catching Covid outdoors. If itaposs in a poorly ventilated area, the risk creeps up to .%. If youaposre wearing a face covering but speaking for a short time to someone who is infected, there is a .% chance of you getting Covid. If the area is poorly ventilated, there is a .% chance, according to the study. The chance of catching Covid increasesthe place has a high volume of people. Brits will be well aware of the three main symptoms of coronavirus – a new, continuous cough, a fever and a loss of taste and or smell. These are the officially recognised symptoms according to the NHS. However, with the new Omicron iant, symptoms have been described as being more similar to a common cold. Itaposs important to be aware of the symptoms in order to limit the spread of Covid. most common symptoms of Omicron, overtaking the  aposclassicapos Covid symptoms Is a rash a symptom of Omicron  Is altered taste a symptom of Omicron  Warning in your eyes doctor warns could be sign of Omicron Warning signs that the Omicron symptoms youaposre experiencing arenapost mind Omicron symptoms parents may be able to spot in children  least pleasant Omicron symptom – including dizziness  According to the chart, you have a % chance of catching Covidyouaposre doing heavy exercise in a poorly ventilated, high occupancy indoor area,youaposre not wearing a face covering and have contact for a long time. title: mum who lost half tongue
story: Mum who lost half her tongue to cancer feels positive with new one made from her legCameron Newsom, , was happy and healthy when she first developed a white spot on her tongue which led to a stage four skin cancer diagnosisCameron Newsom, , first developed a white spot on her tongue Image: Cameron Newsom   SWNSByHarrison MooreKirstie McCrumLeonie Chao-Fong:,  Jan | commentsA mum who lost half of her tongue to cancer has said she is feeling really positive after getting a new one made from her own leg. Cameron Newsom, , first developed a white spot on her tongue and was referred by her dentist to the local hospital for a biopsy. The spot was not painful and, when the results came back negative for any signs of cancer, she and her husband Anthony, also , and their son Hudson, , were told not to worry.But a year later, Cameron, from Colorado Springs, Colorado, developed another identical spot and was admitted to hospital again for a deeper, more invasive biopsy, Bristol Live reports. The results once again showed no signs of cancer but medical experts couldnapost identy the cause of the spots.  Months later, her tongue became sensitive and sore, and immediately contacted her dentist. She was given antibiotics to combat any potential infection but her condition continued to worsen, as the original spots had transformed into a pinkish tumour on the left side of her tongue. She was sent for further tests and a third biopsy and after being referred to an ear nose and throat specialist, Cameron was diagnosed with stage four squamous cell carcinoma – skin cancer of the tongue. Cameron said: At the time of my diagnosis Iaposd lost over seven pounds because I was unable to eat or drink. It took three years from when the first spot originally appeared for doctors to finally diagnose me - no one ever mentioned it could be oral cancer. When I was told, it seemed like I was being handed a death sentence there and then, but straight away my reaction was Iaposm ready to fight this. I was  at the time and in very good shape, so I couldnapost understand why this was happening to me.  When I got home that day I googled my type of cancer and as you can imagine the results were absolutely terrying. There were images of people after having their jaws removed or sawed in half - Iaposd never been so scared. Cameronaposs diagnosis came in May  and she was scheduled in for three rounds of chemo, starting in July and finishing in September that year. Throughout that time, she was unable to eat or drink anything without suffering excruciating pain - all whilst undergoing grueling cancer treatment. There would be times at the dinner table where I would just burst into tears because I couldnapost eat a thing, she said.results showed no signs of cancer - but medical experts couldnapost identy the cause of the spots. Hudson, who was five at the time, didnapost know why I was always so upset and it got to the point where I couldnapost physically speak to him or my husband. A low point for me was when I went to a party with all my closest friends and I had to leave because my mouth was in so much pain. I went home and took a shower to calm down, and thataposs when clumps of my hair started falling out - it was so upsetting. Thankfully for Cameron, her chemotherapy was successful and as a result the tumor had shrunk a considerable amount. Her body had reacted well to the treatment, but the next part of her recovery was to have the tumor completely removed. She then flew back and forth to the MD Anderson Cancer Center in Houston, Texas to meet with some of the best oral surgeons in the country and organise the operation. On December , Cameron went under the kne, and oral and plastic surgeons worked together to remove the left side of her tongue. In what was a nine-and-a-half hour operation, they then replaced that part of her tongue with skin and muscle tissue from her thigh. Surgeons then performed a Tracheotomy on Cameron, where they sliced a hole between her two collar bones and inserted a tube into her neck so she could breathe. The mum also had a feeding tube taped to her nose so she could ingest vital calories which were desperately needed to help her body recover. Read More Cameron said: They usually take skin from your forearm, but I’m only five foot two, so I didn’t have enough skin on my forearm to replace what I was having removed. However, Iaposve been an athlete all my le, and there was plenty for them to use from my thigh - so thataposs what we decided to do. The oral surgeon removed part of my tongue, and the plastic surgeon took muscle and skin from my thigh to replace it. When I woke up I had tubes coming out my neck and nose which allowed me to breathe and eat. The next few weeks were hell because my mouth was so swollen I couldnapost swallow or breathe unassisted. I had to be under constant observation and every time my throat had a build up of blood and body fluid, it had to be flushed away using water. That was basically like being waterboarded by the nurses once or twice a day which was absolutely horric. The weirdest part of the whole experience was when I felt a rough texture on the thigh part of my tongue - and when I looked in the mirror it had started growing leg hair! For nine weeks after her surgery, Cameron underwent  rounds of radiation and another three rounds of chemo to rid of any remaining cancer cells. In that time she was unable to speak, and for six months had to use a tube inserted in her stomach to eat and drink whilst her wounds healed. From then on, Cameron started getting used to le with her new tongue - which included relearning how to speak, chew, drink and swallow. I had to teach myself how to speak again after the radiation therapy which was a really bizarre feeling, she said. I can only taste on the right side of my tongue which is the real side, and only chew on the right side because the left is attached to my gums. My manners are terrible because food sometimes just falls out my mouth, and when food gets stuck underneath my tongue it feels like having a small rock in your shoe. Because the left side is sewn to my gums I donapost have the full range of motion I used to which can be frustrating. A feeling I could compare it to is like having a dead arm or dead leg all the time - it is constantly tingly and numb. Only the healthy side produces saliva and I cant stick my tongue out my mouth at all, so licking things is a big no no! Itaposs now been nine years since my diagnosis and thereaposs been no signs of regression. The longer you go without regressing the less likely it is the cancer will come back, so were all feeling really positive.  was the toughest year of my le and I couldnapost of done it without the support of my amazing Antony and the rest of my family. In June , once she proved she could eat and drink unaided, Cameron ed to her job as a gymnastics coach and was finally able to start living le again. She has since mentored several other people whoaposve been diagnosed with the same cancer as she was, offering them support and guidance throughout their treatment. story: Astronomers spot spooky object never seen before sending mysterious signalsAstronomers from Curtin University, in Australia, have found a mysterious object in space that shines bright and then quickly disappears in a way that has not been seen beforeAstronomers have found a strange new object in space Image: PAByTim HanlonNews Reporter:,  Jan | comments A spooky object that keeps shining and then disappearing in space has been spotted by astronomers who say it is unlike anything seen before.The object appears to release a giant burst of energy three times an hour before disappearing, which has left astronomers scratching their heads. As it spins through space it sends out a beam of radiation, and for one minute in every twenty minutes it is one of the brightest objects in the sky. Researchers think the object could be a neutron star or a white dwarf - collapsed cores of stars - with an ultra-powerful magnetic field.Astrophysicist Dr Natasha Hurley-Walker, of Curtin University, International Centre for Radio Astronomy Researchin Australia, who led the team that made the discovery, called it spooky. She said: This object was appearing and disappearing over a few hours during our observations. That was completely unexpected. It was kind of spooky for an astronomer because thereaposs nothing known in the sky that does that. And itaposs really quite close to us - about , lightyears away. Itaposs in our galactic backyard. Dr Hurley-Walker added that the observations match a predicted astrophysical object called an ultra-long period magnetar. She said: Itaposs a type of slowly spinning neutron star that has been predicted to exist theoretically. But nobody expected to directly detect one like this, because we didnapost expect them to be so bright. Somehow itaposs converting magnetic energy to radio waves much more effectively than anything weaposve seen before. Curtin University Honours student Tyrone OaposDoherty discovered the object using the Murchison Widefield Arraytelescope in outback Western Australia - and a new technique he developed. He said: Itaposs exciting that the source I identied last year has turned out to be such a peculiar object. The Mirroraposs newsletter brings you the latest news, exciting showbiz and TV stories, sport updates and essential political information.The newsletter is emailed out first thing every morning, at noon and every evening. Never miss a moment by signing up to our newsletter here.  Objects that turn on and off in the universe are not new, and astronomers call them transients, with some appearing over the course of a few days and disappearing after a few months, and others flashing on and off within milliseconds or seconds. However, ICRAR-Curtin astrophysicist and co-author Dr Gemma Anderson said finding something that turned on for just a minute made the new discovery unusual. She explained that the mysterious object was incredibly bright and smaller than the sun, emitting the kind of radio waves that suggested it had an extremely strong magnetic field. The researchers are now monitoring the object to seeit switches back on, and plan to search for ore of these unusual objects in the vast archives of the MWA. More detections will tell astronomers whether this was a rare one-off event or a vast new population weaposd never noticed before, Dr Hurley-Walker said. The findings are published in the Nature journal. story: Inside US lab where  frozen people are waiting to be brought back to leThe Alcor Le Extension Foundation stores frozen heads and bodies at its lab in Scottsdale Arizona and believes science will one day be able to revive themCryopreservative Hugh Hixon fills a container meant to hold a patients brain with liquid nitrogen Image: Gamma-Rapho via Getty ImagesByLaura SharmanNews Reporter:,  Jan | commentsFrozen heads and bodies of  people are being stored in a lab in the hope that they can be brought back to le in the future. A whole body can be frozen for slightly under £, while just the head and brain costs around £,. The process, known as cryonics, is being offered by the Alcor Le Extension Foundation. Alcor runs under the belief that science and technology will advance to the point that it can bring back the dead in the future.Bodies are sent to Scottsdale Arizona, where the company is based, and stored at deep freeze temperatures for decades or even centuries, reports The Sun.Experts slowly lower the temperature and store the bodies in a giant vessel of liquid nitrogen at - degrees.  Each body is typically packed in ice and frozen before the blood is replaced with a cryoprotectant formula to prevent ice crystals form forming. Linda and Fred Chamberlain founded the company in . The couple met at a cryonics conference in early  when Fred was working as a NASA engineer and Linda was in college.She told CNET : Our goals were to start an organisation that could save peopleaposs lives and give them an opportunity to be restored to health and . If weaposd known how hard it was going to be, we might not have tried to do it. But once you get started, something about saving lives, you canapost give up. Cryonics supporters believe that death is a process of deterioration and not the moment the heart stops. But critics have dismissed the industry as science fiction or even fraud.One of the bodies held by Alcor belongs to two-year-old Matheryn Naoatpong, who was nicknamed Einz.  The toddleraposs parents, from Thailand, vowed to do all they could to keep their daughter alive after she was diagnosed with a rare brain cancer in . Desperate to find a way to save their little girl, Sahatorn and Nareerat Naoatpong turned to an extreme solution. When it became clear no medical intervention could stop the ceaseless march through Einzaposs body, they were determined Einz would have her body frozen to enable her to have the chance to live again. title: russia could use deception tactic
story: Exclusive: Russia could use deception tactic to keep NATO guessing, security experts fearAround , Russian combat troops are gathered close to the Ukraine border, along with , pro-Moscow separatists in contested Donbas. Nato is bolstering its deterrence in the Baltic Sea regionRussian President Vladimir Putin Image: Alexei Nikolsky TASSByChris HughesDefence and Security Editor:,  Jan | commentsRussian air force chiefs sparked an attack scare by planting war plane transponders on military vehicles, it was claimed tonight. The ruse looked like  military planes grouping up and moving in circles at west Russian airports close to the Ukraine border.If it was a “spoof manoeuvre” security experts suspect it was to hide another “activity” happening where and keep NATO guessing. British Rivet Joint spy planes are known to have been flying patrols over Ukraine to hoover up Russian radio chatter and other communications. They are there to provide an early warning of where and when an attack might be launched by Russian forces moving into Ukraine.  Alarmingly Moscow’s air force planes have been steadily increasing in number in airports to the west of Russia without being involved in exercises. Around , Russian combat troops are gathered close to the Ukraine border, along with , pro-Moscow separatists in contested Donbas. Russia also has a large number of regular and special forces bolstering Donbas separatists, although Moscow has repeatedly denied this. An expert in Russian military matters told the Daily Mirror: “I havenapost seen anything like this before. Air force people in the UK are baffled.  “Circuiting round and round and up and down a large airfield is not a recognised manoeuvre. “These aircraft could be seen moving all day, burning fuel. “So it was likely a spoof with jeeps or cars meandering around with transponders on them. “This could mean not that nothing is happening, but something is happening where that we cannot detect.  Russia has warned it would quickly take retaliatory measuresthe US and its allies reject its security demands regarding NATO membership. Russia has demanded guarantees that Nato will never admit Ukraine and other ex-Soviet nations as members and that the alliance will roll back troop deployments in ex-Soviet bloc countries. Russian foreign minister Sergei Lavrov said he and other top officials would advise President Vladimir Putin on the next steps after receiving written replies from the US to the demands. He said: If the West continues its aggressive course, Moscow will take the necessary retaliatory measures. Nato is bolstering its deterrence in the Baltic Sea region and the US ordered , troops on higher alert for potential deployment to Europe. Western nations including the UK have also sent plane loads of weapons to help Ukraine strengthen its defences. story: Woman, , dresses up like adult baby, uses dummies and even wears nappiesLucy Anne, from New Jersey, said she wanted to revert to a baby-like state from a young age and now enjoys relaxing at home wearing onesies, nappies and dummiesLucy Anne wearing a nappy and pacier Image: MERCURY PRESSByJade CulverLaura SharmanNews Reporter:,  Jan | commentsA -year-old woman has revealed how she dresses like a baby and even uses dummies and nappies. Lucy Anne, from New Jersey, US, first realised her desire to revert back to infancy at the age of nine but only began acting like a baby aged . The cyber-security analyst spends her time at home lounging around in nappies, onesies and dummies while also selling pictures of herself dressed as a baby online. Despite this, Lucy claims she does not dress up as a baby for sexual reasons, but for comfort and acceptance after years of resenting how she felt. She said: “These feelings and desire to revert to a baby-like state started when I was really young. “I didn’t understand them at the time and I grew up hating how I felt. “As a teen, I experimented by wearing diapers and started to explore the ‘adult baby diaper lover’community after thinking about it for over ten years.  Lucy said she became involved with the ABDL community with an ex-partner, who was also part of it, and has since worn onesies and nappies to relax at home.She added: “I opened an Instagram to share my images because I feel cute and will sometimes get direct messages where people will ask me for specic photos or will just send me money because they like my content.“I’ve made £ from commissions but I’ve probably made more from people who have sent me money to buy new stuffed animals, paciers or diapers. “I actually have one contributor who actually sends me £ of adult diapers each month.” Lucy’s acting age range is between three and five years old and she tries to immerse herself in the experience as much as possible. She said: “I really want the experience of being a baby to be as realistic as possible and knew I couldn’t just do that with a diaper. “I use the diapers for the reason they are intended for and find that it actually helps me sleep through the night without being disturbed by weak bladder issues. “I sometimes will wear a diaper to work, hidden under everyday work clothes. “I have a collection of paciers, pyjama onesies that have a flap on the bottom for easy access and lots of cute fleece blankets. “Stuffed toys also make up a big part of my baby collection, and I also have a few cat ears to match. Due to her interests and desire to revert back to a baby, Lucy often gets requests she is uncomfortable with as well as struggling to reveal her lestyle to some family members and friends. She said: “As I’ve never seen this as a sexual thing, when I get sexual requests, I am quite uncomfortable and will always try and ignore it. “One of the grossest requests askedI could dry hump one of my stuffed animals on a video call, so they were blocked immediately. “When my mum found out, it took her a while to understand it, but she came around when she realised I was doing it in private and not causing any harm. “A few of my friends think it’s a bit weird but know that it’s just a part of who I am. “I’ve always wanted to reveal myself to my dad and other family members, but I’m not sure they’d understand.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON AnimalsOnesiesGiant babies" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you.
